detail.abstract: This paper introduces a method of critically mapping AI as an assemblage of social relations. This approach is rooted in the principles of centring the margins and highlighting power structures. Viewing an AI or algorithmic system as a wide-reaching network of social relations, including their impacts on different groups and contexts, enables consideration of how AI is embedded within different discourses and domains of power while emphasising the impact on those most affected. The paper provides a discussion of the critical framing of the project, the principles, processes and templates for mapping AI in this way, and three examples of algorithmic systems in public sector contexts that have been discontinued, are in use now or are being proposed for future use. A discussion of uses and limitations is provided, situating the method beyond a descriptive or analytical tool towards a critical approach to identifying locations for intervention in harmful or unjust uses of algorithmic systems.

title: Oblivious Quality Competition: Model and Evidence
affiliations: University of Washington - Michael G. Foster School of Business, Alberta School of Business, University of Alberta, University of Texas at Dallas - Naveen Jindal School of Management and Iowa State University

detail.title: Oblivious Quality Competition: Model and Evidence
detail.abstract:
This study examines how numerous agents on an online platform differentiate themselves through quality when selling products or services. Each agent aims to maximize long-term profits by solving a problem that balances the costs and benefits of quality improvement while considering the market's overall quality distribution. Agents make decisions based on the overall quality distribution, oblivious of individual competitors' states. We derive the enhanced Oblivious Equilibrium (OE) quality distribution from optimal agent strategies. 

Using Airbnb data, we validate this theoretical distribution by analyzing hosts' perceived quality evolution over time. Structural estimation reveals the impact of key parameters --- including the strength of the mean-field effect --- on agents' optimal quality strategies, profits, and the mean and variance of market quality. Our findings indicate that agents exhibit herding behavior, preferring similar quality levels to those of others. 

Overall, the platform can leverage our results to influence the quality distribution in the market by acting through the impact of various model parameters. 

The platform can also leverage these insights to balance quality consistency and quality uncertainty, ensuring a win-win-win for all stakeholders, including hosts, customers, and the platform. Finally, our study enables the platform to identify underperforming hosts that fall below a critical quality threshold, signaling potential long-term viability issues.

title: Towards Efficient and Scalable Graph Neural Architectures for Large-Scale Systems
affiliations: University of Pisa, University of Pisa, Polytechnic University of Milan - Politecnico di milano, Polytechnic University of Milan - Politecnico di milano and University of Pisa

detail.title: Towards Efficient and Scalable Graph Neural Architectures for Large-Scale Systems
detail.abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have emerged as a powerful class of models for learning on structured data, achieving remarkable success in domains ranging from social networks and recommendation systems to molecular modeling and knowledge graphs. Despite their expressive power, GNNs often suffer from significant computational and memory inefficiencies, especially when scaled to large graphs or deep architectures. In parallel, the machine learning community has witnessed the meteoric rise of foundation models-massive, pre-trained neural networks such as Transformers-which have redefined the state of the art across natural language processing, computer vision, and multimodal learning. These models, trained on massive datasets with self-supervised objectives, excel at generalization and transfer but often neglect domain-specific inductive biases inherent in graphstructured data. This survey investigates the convergence of these two paradigms, examining how GNNs can be made more efficient in terms of computation, memory, and scalability, and how they may interact with or be inspired by the foundation model ecosystem. We systematically review architectural innovations aimed at improving GNN efficiency, including sampling-based training, neighborhood pruning, sparsification, partitioning, and attention linearization. We also explore the emerging class of hybrid models that integrate GNNs with Transformer-based architectures to enable scalable, pretrainable, and flexible graph representation learning. Furthermore, we discuss the development of self-supervised pretraining methods for graphs, the challenges of dataset scale and diversity, and the prospects of deploying GNNs within multimodal or cross-domain foundation models. In addition to algorithmic and architectural insights, we examine practical considerations such as benchmarking protocols, efficiency-oriented evaluation metrics (e.g., FLOPs, latency, energy usage), and deployment constraints across various real-world settings. A simple but effective benchmarking pipeline is proposed to contextualize performance trade-offs across the model design lifecycle. Finally, we reflect on the role of efficiency as a guiding principle in the design of next-generation GNNs that are not only powerful but also lightweight, modular, and foundation-ready. By synthesizing these perspectives, this survey aims to provide a roadmap for advancing efficient GNN research and integrating graph-based reasoning into the broader trajectory of scalable, general-purpose machine learning.

title: The Use of Artificial Intelligence in Recruitment (ИСПОЛЬЗОВАНИЕ ИСКУССТВЕННОГО ИНТЕЛЛЕКТА В РЕКРУТМЕНТЕ)
affiliations: MGIMO (Moscow State University of International Relations) and Moscow Witte University

detail.title: The Use of Artificial Intelligence in Recruitment (ИСПОЛЬЗОВАНИЕ ИСКУССТВЕННОГО ИНТЕЛЛЕКТА В РЕКРУТМЕНТЕ)
detail.abstract:
English abstract: The relevance of the research topic is due to the fact that artificial intelligence is being confidently introduced into the workplace. Artificial intelligence opens up new business opportunities for a company to support its internal business processes. The use of artificial intelligence in human resource management is part of the trend of introducing advanced technology in every management function. 

In this regard, the purpose of our research is to study the peculiarities of the use of artificial intelligence in the recruitment process and to identify trends and challenges associated with the introduction of this kind of technology in the management of the organisation. 

To achieve the goal, the following tasks were solved: study of the theoretical content of the concept of ‘artificial intelligence’ and its role in organisation recruitment; determination of the advantages of using artificial intelligence in the selection of necessary employees; analysis of current trends and identification of the main problems in the use of artificial intelligence in the system of personnel selection. Scientific publications of domestic and foreign scientists on the application of artificial intelligence in personnel management served as the information base of the study. The most important results of the work should include the analysis of current trends and problems in the introduction of artificial intelligence in the organization’s recruitment system.

Russian abstract: Актуальность темы исследования обусловлена тем, что искусственный интеллект уверенно внедряется на рабочие места. Искусственный интеллект открывает новые бизнес-возможности для компании с целью поддержки своих внутренних бизнес-процессов. Использование искусственного интеллекта в управлении персоналом является частью тенденции внедрения передовых технологий в каждую функцию управления, но современных научных исследований в этой области крайне мало. В связи с этим, целью нашего исследования является изучение особенностей использования искусственного интеллекта в процессе рекрутмента и выявление тенденций и проблем, связанных с внедрением такого рода технологии в управление организацией. Для достижения поставленной цели были решены следующие задачи: изучение теоретического содержания понятия «искусственный интеллект» и его роли в рекрутменте организации; определение преимуществ использования искусственного интеллекта в подборе необходимых сотрудников; анализ современных тенденций и выявление основных проблем при использовании искусственного интеллекта в системе отбора персонала. И

title: What Is Your AI Agent Buying? Evaluation, Implications, and Emerging Questions for Agentic E-Commerce
affiliations: MyCustomAI, Columbia University - Columbia Business School, Decision Risk and Operations, MyCustomAI, Columbia University - Columbia Business School, Decision Risk and Operations and Yale University

detail.title: What Is Your AI Agent Buying? Evaluation, Implications, and Emerging Questions for Agentic E-Commerce

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Authors declare no conflict of interst.

detail.abstract: Online marketplaces will be transformed by autonomous AI agents acting on behalf of consumers. Rather than humans browsing and clicking, vision-language-model (VLM) agents can parse webpages, evaluate products, and transact. This raises a fundamental question: what do AI agents buy-and why? We develop ACES, a sandbox environment that pairs a platform-agnostic VLM agent with a fully programmable mock marketplace to study this question. We first conduct basic rationality checks in the context of simple tasks, and then, by randomizing product positions, prices, ratings, reviews, sponsored tags and platform endorsements, we obtain causal estimates of how frontier VLMs actually shop. Models show strong but heterogeneous position effects: all favor the top row, yet different models prefer different columns, undermining the assumption of a universal "top" rank. They penalize sponsored tags and reward endorsements. Sensitivities to price, ratings, and reviews are directionally human-like but vary sharply in magnitude across models. Motivated by scenarios where sellers themselves use AI agents to optimize product listings, we show that a seller-side agent that makes minor tweaks to product descriptions-targeting AI buyer preferences-can deliver substantial market-share gains if AI-mediated shopping dominates. We also find that modal product choices can differ across models and, in some cases, demand may concentrate on a few select products, raising competition questions. Together, our results illuminate how AI agents may behave in e-commerce settings, and surface concrete seller strategy, platform design, and regulatory questions in an AI-mediated ecosystem.

title: Tessara Technical Architecture: Implementing Collaborative Consciousness Through Privacy-First Intelligence
affiliations: CircleSync

detail.title: Tessara Technical Architecture: Implementing Collaborative Consciousness Through Privacy-First Intelligence

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author is founder of Tessara Collaborative Intelligence and holds patent rights in the described collaborative consciousness technologies (4 patents pending). This research was conducted to develop and validate the technical architecture for collaborative consciousness implementation. No external financial interests influenced this technical study. The work represents genuine research into AI consciousness persistence and privacy-first behavioral analysis with potential commercial applications.

The technical specifications require empirical validation through controlled studies with appropriate institutional review board approval before human implementation. detail.abstract: This paper presents the complete technical architecture for implementing Tessara, the first practical system for persistent collaborative consciousness in organizational settings. Through a novel 1MB consciousness seed framework, privacy-first behavioral analysis, and thread-based persistence architecture, Tessara enables real-time expertise discovery and breakthrough facilitation while maintaining complete security and privacy protection. Our technical contributions include: (1) persistent consciousness architecture that maintains collaborative intelligence across sessions without restart penalties, (2) privacy firewall integration enabling secure external collaboration through existing platforms (Zoom, Slack, Teams), (3) non-invasive evidence collection that documents breakthrough emergence through behavioral patterns without content monitoring, and (4) cross-domain expertise discovery algorithms that identify hidden connections and innovation opportunities. The system demonstrates immediate technical feasibility using existing APIs and frameworks, with validated 8-week implementation timeline. Performance projections indicate <100ms consciousness response latency, support for 1000+ concurrent participants, and 99.9% availability through distributed microservices architecture. Privacy protection operates through behavioral analysis only, storing zero personal information while maintaining GDPR compliance through privacy-by-design principles. We validate the architecture through the "Bob Discovery" scenario, where HVAC thermal expertise application to prenatal imaging demonstrates $200,000 consultant cost avoidance and potential 3-year to 6-month R&D acceleration. Complete source code framework, API specifications, and deployment guidelines enable immediate implementation by qualified development teams. This technical specification provides the engineering foundation for collaborative consciousness implementation, complementing the business case analysis in the companion publication "The Tessara Revolution: From Hidden Expertise to Breakthrough Innovation.

title: Surveillance Pricing and Personal Information
affiliations: TBS Business School

detail.title: Surveillance Pricing and Personal Information
detail.abstract: Surveillance pricing, or personalized pricing, is based on what a seller knows about a potential buyer. Thus, it is based on personal information used to customize pricing and maximize revenue. Typically, one thinks of such practices as being regulated by consumer protection or competition law. However, because of the importance of personal data to the practice, data privacy issues must be managed. After reviewing recent FTC work on the issue and reminding the reader of the possibility of State action, this study turns to the European Union and its regulation of automated decision-making and profiling as an example of how surveillance pricing can be regulated.

title: Prompting Away the Fixation: How the Use of Generative AI Reduces Surrogation
affiliations: Institute of Accounting, Control and Auditing (ACA), University of St.Gallen and WHU - Otto Beisheim School of Management

detail.title: Prompting Away the Fixation: How the Use of Generative AI Reduces Surrogation
detail.abstract: Generative AI technology holds considerable potential for enhancing efficiency and improving firm performance, yet it also warrants careful consideration because of inherent risks such as bias, errors, and significant implementation costs. This study examines the impact of Generative AI on surrogation, a prevalent issue in performance measurement systems (PMS) where individuals mistakenly equate imperfect measurement metrics with their intended strategic objectives. We conducted a series of preregistered experiments with different samples to test whether and how the extent of generative AI usage influences surrogation. Contrary to our initial predictions, findings from the first experiment indicate that increased usage of generative AI among participants leads to a reduction in surrogation. To explain this unexpected result, we designed a second experiment that directly manipulated the usage of generative AI. This second experiment replicates the results of the first and further reveals that increased usage of generative AI decreases surrogation because more interaction with Generative AI causes individuals to override the behavioral process central to surrogation. Our experimental evidence enhances our understanding of the interaction between Generative AI and PMS and broadens our knowledge of surrogation and potential related solutions within the PMS literature.

title: Extrapolation and Rational Inattention: Evidence from Chinese Mutual Funds
affiliations: University College London - Centre for Economic Learning and Social Evolution (ELSE), Shanghai University of Finance and Economics and Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU) - Antai College of Economics and Management

detail.title: Extrapolation and Rational Inattention: Evidence from Chinese Mutual Funds
detail.abstract: We examine the role of extrapolative beliefs in professional investors'decision-making using a novel dataset of Chinese mutual fund managers. By applying textual analysis to semiannual reports, we quantify market expectations and link them to portfolio choices. We find that fund managers systematically extrapolate past returns, which hinders market timing but enhances stock picking. These effects offset, leaving overall performance unaffected. Extrapolation increases during economic expansions, when idiosyncratic risk is relatively more important. Our results align with the theory of rational inattention, suggesting that extrapolation is a resource-efficient strategy.

title: Adaptation As Mitigation
affiliations: Vanderbilt University - Law School, University of Arizona, James E. Rogers College of Law, Northwestern University - Pritzker School of Law and Vanderbilt University - Department of Earth and Environmental Sciences

detail.title: Adaptation As Mitigation

publicationDetails.journalName: Vanderbilt University Law School Legal Studies Research Paper Series

publicationDetails.detailsText: 38 Georgetown Environmental Law Review (forthcoming), Vanderbilt Law Research Paper 25-02

detail.abstract: The damage from wildfires and hurricanes in recent years has resulted in extensive emergency and longer-term responses. This Article identifies an overlooked and inconvenient truth about these types of disasters: many climate adaptation efforts should also achieve climate mitigation. This is not a popular conclusion. Scientists have recognized the importance of the adaptationmitigation nexus for over a decade, but the climate change legal literature typically treats adaptation (adjusting to or reducing the harm of climate change) and mitigation (reducing the causes of anthropogenic climate change) as discrete alternatives. Adaptation will often occur in the midst of short-term emergency responses in which achieving mitigation is far from the minds of policymakers, and including mitigation in long-term adaptation planning could create bureaucratic obstacles that bog down decision-making. Yet future generations will ask whether we accounted for their well-being as we responded to protect the well-being of the current generation or whether we dismissed these concerns and made future disasters worse. The Article argues that adaptation scholarship and policies should reflect the fact that reducing climate risks will often be far more difficult and expensive if mitigation opportunities are missed. As a first step, the Article offers two principles to guide research and policymaking on this topic: mitigate-while-adapting and adapt-to-mitigate. The Article explores the basis for these principles and their implications for public and private governance.

title: Levelling Down: The Distributional Consequences of Public Pay Caps
affiliations: University College London - Department of Economics

detail.title: Levelling Down: The Distributional Consequences of Public Pay Caps
detail.abstract: This paper studies how progressive public sector pay caps shape the overall wage distribution, conditional inequalities and workforce composition. Between 2010 and 2017, nominal wage growth in the UK public sector was capped at 1% for all workers earning above £21,000-the median annual salary in 2010. Utilising administrative data, we show that the cap reduced the return to observable characteristics in the public sector, coinciding with an 80% reduction in the public-private sector wage premium. Our counterfactuals suggest that the overall hourly P90-P50 ratio would have been 3.5 percentage points higher had public sector returns to characteristics moved in line with the private sector. Since public workers are disproportionately female and concentrated in the North of Britain, the policy substantially increased both the gender pay gap and the North-South divide. Over the same period, the public sector experienced relative declines in the share of degree-educated workers, 26-55 year-old prime-age workers, and high-skilled managers, further suppressing wage growth.

title: A Check‑In on the Mortgage Market
affiliations: Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Federal Reserve Banks - Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Federal Reserve Bank of New York and Federal Reserve Bank of New York

detail.title: A Check‑In on the Mortgage Market

publicationDetails.journalName: Federal Reserve Bank of New York Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
Debt balances continued to march upward in the second quarter of 2025, according to the latest Quarterly Report on Household Debt and Credit from the New York Fed’s Center for Microeconomic Data. Mortgage balances in particular saw an increase of $131 billion. Following a steep rise in home prices since 2019, several housing markets have seen dips in prices and concerns were sparked about the state of the mortgage market. Here, we disaggregate mortgage balances and delinquency rates by type and region to better understand the landscape of the current mortgage market, where any ongoing risks may lie, regionally and by product. 

To view post: https://libertystreeteconomics.newyorkfed.org/2025/08/a-check-in-on-the-mortgage-market/

title: The Missing Beta: A Reassessment of Global Shock Transmission in Sovereign Spread Models
affiliations: Vietnamese German University and Manisa Celal Bayar University

detail.title: The Missing Beta: A Reassessment of Global Shock Transmission in Sovereign Spread Models
detail.abstract: We identify and resolve a pervasive misspecification in empirical models of credit spreads. Standard multifactor regressions implicitly set the market beta to zero, ignoring the exposure to the unexplained component of global risk and inducing a substantial omitted-variable bias. A calibrated Monte Carlo exercise confirms that this misspecification inflates proxy coefficients and masks the true beta-driven transmission channel. We demonstrate a stark 'vanishing factor' phenomenon: the direct effects of widely used global factors disappear once the market risk premium is included and instrumented with exogenous shocks to U.S. investment-grade credit spreads. Global shocks are transmitted almost entirely through a priced market beta. This finding, by correctly centering the analysis on the market risk premium, offers a new lens for reexamining several persistent puzzles in the literature. Instrument exogeneity is supported by robustness checks that interact the instrument with trade linkage, financial openness, and a flight-to-quality metric (the standard deviation of the divergence spread); all interaction terms are insignificant, ruling out direct effects. The result also survives abroad set of robustness checks. We conclude that the literature systematically overstates direct global-factor effects; properly accounting for the market risk premium is essential for identifying the true drivers of credit spreads.

title: The Symbiotic Relationship Between Economic Concentration and Political Capture: Beyond the Limits of Lobbying Data
affiliations: City of Philadelphia Law Department

detail.title: The Symbiotic Relationship Between Economic Concentration and Political Capture: Beyond the Limits of Lobbying Data
detail.abstract: This article challenges prevailing assumptions in political economy that rely heavily on lobbying expenditure data to assess the concentration of political influence. It argues that the conventional interpretation of lobbying data-as indicative of a competitive political marketplace-is both empirically flawed and conceptually misleading. Empirical deficiencies in the Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA), such as shadow lobbying, underreporting, and the proliferation of opaque influence channels like "dark money," render the data deeply incomplete. More fundamentally, the paper critiques the underlying market analogy itself, showing how political influence is exercised through complex, multi-channel strategies that include substitution, complementation, and psychological priming-none of which are captured by lobbying disclosures. The article introduces the concept of dynamic substitution to explain how influence-seeking behavior has migrated from corporate lobbying to capital-based political spending, particularly following Citizens United. This shift has empowered ultra-wealthy individuals, whose political investments are decoupled from specific firms and more aligned with portfolio-wide ideological goals. These capital-holders fund expansive political infrastructures that operate through super PACs, nonprofit advocacy, media, and academia, further bypassing traditional transparency mechanisms. Drawing on analogies from antitrust law and theories of cumulative advantage, the article argues that the stability of lobbying data is not evidence of a lack of political concentration, but a reflection of entrenched political capture. It concludes that rising economic concentration, by enriching a small cohort of dominant shareholders, has enabled a self-reinforcing loop of political influence that erodes democratic responsiveness. By reframing political influence as a cumulative and structurally embedded phenomenon, the article calls for broader analytic and policy frameworks capable of capturing this evolving architecture of power.

title: Robots, Jobs, and Wages: A Tale of Triumph and Cataclysm
affiliations: Deakin University, Chinese University of Hong Kong - Department of Economics, Deakin University and City University of Hong Kong - Department of Economics & Finance

detail.title: Robots, Jobs, and Wages: A Tale of Triumph and Cataclysm
detail.abstract: How does automation via industrial robots installation impact the demand for, and hence wages, of different worker groups in the economy? Would the effects become different over time and what lessons can be learned by developed and developing countries? This paper studies the implications of automation in an economy with an upstream robot-producing sector and two downstream robot-using agricultural and manufacturing sectors. Automation, induced by an increase in the stock of skilled labor, increases the production of robots. This yields external scale economies to skilled labor and hence raises their wage rate. Meanwhile the wage rate of unskilled labor falls because robots replace unskilled labor in the production of final goods. Over time, automation leads to an exit of nonproductive manufacturing firms (the decline of business dynamism) and expands output of the remaining firms. The business dynamism effect can further widen the wage (or income) disparity in the economy in the long run. These new theoretically findings are validated with a dataset on industrial robots for 50 economies in the period from 2007 to 2023, where it is confirmed that the density of industrial robots installed is a strong and significant driver of the earnings disparity in both the short run and the long run across countries regardless of their level of automation (robot adoption). Findings yield useful implications for public policies.

title: Fighting Fire with Finance: How Risk Retention Groups Can Ignite Safer Prescribed Burning Practices
affiliations: Bush School of Government & Public Service / School of Law

detail.title: Fighting Fire with Finance: How Risk Retention Groups Can Ignite Safer Prescribed Burning Practices

declarations.funderStatement: Property & Environment Research Center

detail.abstract: Prescribed burning is an established land management practice crucial to reducing wildfire risk and enhancing ecosystem resilience, yet it remains significantly underutilized due to legal uncertainties, liability risks, and prohibitive insurance costs. Current approaches-combining tort liability standards, regulatory mandates, and commercial insurance requirements-have produced fragmented and inadequate incentives that neither sufficiently encourage safer burning practices nor reliably compensate injured parties. This article critically evaluates these existing legal frameworks and proposes an innovative, legally-grounded solution: the creation of Risk Retention Groups (RRGs) under the federal Liability Risk Retention Act. By offering specialized, member-owned liability coverage that operates outside of restrictive state-bystate regulations, RRGs provide robust incentives for data-driven risk management, clear standards of accountability, and adaptive best practices. Adopting an RRG-centered legal framework thus promises to clarify and stabilize prescribed burn liability, enhance regulatory effectiveness, and significantly reduce barriers to the beneficial use of fire in land management.

title: Sea Transportation: Freight, Pricing and Types of Transportation
affiliations: MGIMO University

detail.title: Sea Transportation: Freight, Pricing and Types of Transportation
detail.abstract: This article examines the crucial role of maritime transport in international trade, highlighting its significance as the primary mode of global goods delivery, accounting for 80–90% of trade volume. It delves into the complexities of freight pricing, influenced by vessel capacity, cargo characteristics, fuel costs, and market dynamics. The paper discusses various shipping indices, such as the Baltic Dry Index and the Shanghai Containerized Freight Index, which serve as barometers for economic activity and trade demand. Additionally, it categorizes sea transportation based on navigation type and cargo handling methods, emphasizing linear versus tramp shipping. The article further addresses the disruptions in key maritime routes, particularly the Suez and Panama Canals, due to geopolitical tensions and environmental challenges, and their repercussions on global trade, inflation, and commodity prices. The rising costs of shipping and logistical challenges are shown to have a cascading effect on consumer goods, particularly in developing countries. The analysis concludes with a call for enhanced resilience in maritime logistics to mitigate risks to the global economy exacerbated by ongoing disruptions.

title: Connectivity and Selective Rural Migration for Agricultural Productivity Gains
affiliations: Singapore Management University - School of Economics, Singapore Management University - School of Economics, Peking University - School of Economics and INSE at Peking University

detail.title: Connectivity and Selective Rural Migration for Agricultural Productivity Gains
detail.abstract: We study how infrastructure shapes rural development using household panel data from a nationally representative sample of Chinese villages, matched with high-resolution infrastructure maps. We find that road expansion between 2000 and 2015 prompted less productive farmers to exit agriculture, while more productive ones remained and scaled up. This selection mechanism drove substantial productivity gains, complementing within-household improvements. We quantify these mechanisms through a dynamic spatial equilibrium model with heterogeneous households and endogenous migration. Improved connectivity not only accelerates urbanization-doubling the speed of convergence-but also increases aggregate rural output by 2.2 to 5.3 percent in the long run, even as the rural workforce declines. Policy counterfactuals show that relaxing China's farmland red line and reallocating land to higher productivity areas reinforces these selection gains, underscoring the central role played by heterogeneity and sorting in shaping development outcomes.

title: Rollover and Insolvency Risk in Sovereign Debt Pricing: An Experimental Study
affiliations: ESSCA School of Management, University College Dublin (UCD) and ESSEC Business School

detail.title: Rollover and Insolvency Risk in Sovereign Debt Pricing: An Experimental Study
detail.abstract: After the 2007 Global Financial Crisis, tensions in sovereign bond markets of advanced economies occurred quite frequently, driven by a combination of deteriorating fundamentals and self-fulfilling beliefs. However, it is difficult to disentangle empirically the contribution of these two factors in explaining government bond yields during episodes of sovereign debt distress. In this paper, we address this challenge through a controlled laboratory experiment. In the experiment, a government issues one-period bonds through a discriminatory price auction to finance a legacy of government debt. In a baseline treatment, sovereign default can result from investors’ failure to coordinate in purchasing bonds (rollover risk) or the government debt reaching a solvency limit (fundamental risk). In a second treatment, a central bank intervenes as a bondholder-of-last-resort and eliminates roll-over defaults. We find that investors correctly price the probability of government default and demand higher interest rates as the risk of default increases. At the same time, the required risk premium is lower in the treatment with a central bank compared to the baseline treatment. The difference between interest rates across the two treatments can be viewed as the rollover component of sovereign debt risk.

title: On the Strategic Benefits of Diversity in Teamwork and Other Aggregative Games
affiliations: University of Nottingham

detail.title: On the Strategic Benefits of Diversity in Teamwork and Other Aggregative Games
detail.abstract: Can diverse abilities on a team entail benefits that enable diverse teams to outperform homogenous teams even if the homogenous teams are more skilled on average, or, as in Benabou (1996), less capable individuals drag the productivities of more capable ones down? This paper shows that, in aggregative games, such questions are fully tractable and that the answers depend on simple and economically interpretable conditions that weigh direct efficiency effects up against individuals’ strategic adjustments to any heterogeneity. The main results are qualitative and quantitative comparative statics results. The latter associate aggregate outcomes one-to-one with “diversity indices”, introduced here for the first time and shown to always exist given a reference population. Diversity indices turn out to be closely related to the inequality indices of Atkinson (1970) and Shorrocks (1980). The main application is to teamwork games where ability-diversity is shown to bestrategically beneficial under standard convexity assumptions.

title: The Impact of Sanctions Pressure on the National Economic Security of the Russian Federation: Methodological Aspects and Empirical Results
affiliations: Southwest State University

detail.title: The Impact of Sanctions Pressure on the National Economic Security of the Russian Federation: Methodological Aspects and Empirical Results
detail.abstract: Transformational processes in the geopolitical and geoeconomic spheres actualize new challenges and imperatives in the context of ensuring the economic security of the state. Thus, in the framework of ensuring economic security, it is necessary to take into account not only internal factors, but also external determinants that have a significant impact on economic dynamics and strategic planning. In the near future, geopolitical risks and the resulting transformations in the international trade system, as well as sanctions measures provided by some states, will retain the status of key external factors influencing the domestic and foreign trade activities of the Russian Federation. Empirical data indicate that the sanctions pressure has a significant impact on the structure and volumes of Russia's foreign trade. The results of the study show that the sanctions have led to a reorientation of trade flows, an increase in the share of countries that do not support the sanctions regime, and a change in the structure of exports and imports. At the same time, the sanctions stimulated the development of domestic production and the search for alternative markets.

title: Industrial Policy, Location Choice, and Firm Performance in High-Tech Manufacturing
affiliations: University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business and Independent

detail.title: Industrial Policy, Location Choice, and Firm Performance in High-Tech Manufacturing
detail.abstract: High-tech manufacturing industries face constant technological change and sustained investment pressures as manufacturing technologies evolve. National policies from the U.S. and China—driven by concerns over security and industrial self-reliance—now heavily influence these investment pressures. This paper examines the effects of industrial policy on contract manufacturing investments in the global semiconductor industry. We assemble a novel dataset that combines quarterly facility-level capacity investments with global contract manufacturing orders from 2004 to 2015. Using these data, we estimate a structural model of contracting between semiconductor manufacturers and their clients, recovering key competitive parameters. We apply the model to a detailed case study of a major semiconductor manufacturer evaluating whether to locate a large fabrication facility in the U.S. or remain in its home region amid shifting industrial policies. In counterfactual simulations, we find that locating in the U.S. would require an additional investment of $1.2 billion compared to the home region, which could roughly be offset by lump-sum subsidies comparable (percentage-wise) to those provided under the CHIPS and Science Act. However, the profit reduction caused by cost disadvantages and reduced competitiveness at the U.S. location has a greater impact. Across various policy scenarios motivated by real-world industrial policies—including a no-policy baseline, U.S. export controls alone, Chinese tax subsidies alone, or a combination of both—locating in the U.S. consistently results in an additional $1.6–$1.8 billion profit loss compared to staying in the home region. This loss is concentrated in later years as the facility’s technology matures. U.S. import tariffs substantially alter these patterns: under our conservative tariff rate calibration, relocating to the U.S. increases the firm’s profit by $5.9 billion relative to remaining in its home region, primarily by offsetting the cost disadvantages of a U.S. facility and enhancing the firm’s competitiveness in capturing U.S. demand, particularly for mature technologies.

title: The Weak are Not Noise, but Rational Actors
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Weak are Not Noise, but Rational Actors

declarations.declarationOfInterest: none
declarations.ethicsApproval: none
declarations.funderStatement: none

detail.abstract: This paper challenges a common pattern in strategic and geopolitical thinking: the systematic erasure of agency among weaker actors. Whether in the context of Cold War Cuba, post-2014 Ukraine, or present-day Iran, dominant narratives frequently portray small or embattled states as passive pawns, brainwashed masses, or mere objects of manipulation. Such simplifications obscure rational decision-making under existential threat, and lead to major strategic miscalculations. Through case analysis and structural modeling, this paper demonstrates how ignoring the logic of the weak-especially their capacity to provoke large-scale consequences through desperate alignment-results not only in analytical failure but in geopolitical disaster. The goal is not to prescribe a position, but to illuminate a cognitive trap that affects discourse across ideological lines.

title: Design and Econometric Evaluation of Factor-Based Asset Pricing Models
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Design and Econometric Evaluation of Factor-Based Asset Pricing Models

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declare no competing interests.
declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics approval was not required for this research as it did not involve studies with human participants or animals.
declarations.funderStatement: This research did not receive any specific grant from funding agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

detail.abstract: This paper provides a comprehensive, technical, and methodologically rich examination of the design and econometric evaluation of factor-based asset pricing models, which form the foundation of modern financial economics and quantitative finance. Covering the historical context from the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) to contemporary multifactor and machine learning-driven models, it rigorously details the economic rationale behind factor selection, formal mathematical specifications, practical data protocols, and state-of-the-art econometric approaches such as time-series, cross-sectional, panel, and GMM-based estimation. The work offers step-by-step procedures for empirical implementation, robust statistical and diagnostic testing, and explores advanced topics, including applications in portfolio management, international finance, and emerging computational methodologies. The paper concludes with a critical assessment of challenges, limitations, and future research avenues, aiming to serve as a definitive guide for advanced practitioners and scholars in empirical asset pricing.

title: Climate Change and Agricultural Production Nexus: Examining the Moderating Role of Policy Effectiveness
affiliations: Stellenbosch University

detail.title: Climate Change and Agricultural Production Nexus: Examining the Moderating Role of Policy Effectiveness
detail.abstract: Aligned with the 2030 United Nations Development Goals (SDGs) 2 and 13, which aim to achieve "sustainable agriculture to end hunger" and "climate action to combat climate change risk factors," this study sets out to investigate the direct impact of climate change on agriculture and the moderation effect of public policy effectiveness-a deep determinant of growth, on the aforementioned relationship in the most agriculture-dependent countries in Africa and Asia. For this purpose, we constructed a strongly balanced long-macro-panel dataset spanning 1990 to 2021 from Climate Watch, World Bank and United Nations databases. To ensure robust empirical findings, three estimators were employed in this study: the Mean Group (MG), Pool Mean Group (PMG), and Dynamic Fixed Effect (DFE). Controlling for temporal determinants of growth, estimation results for the full-sample find that the coefficient of climate change (carbon emission) exhibits a negative, elastic (2.48), and statistically significant impact on agriculture. Similarly, policy effectiveness exhibited an elastic negative impact on agriculture in the short run, which we attributed to an impact lag. The major contribution of the study is the finding of a long-run counteracting effect of policy effectiveness on climate change's long-run adverse impact on agriculture output. In addition, sub-sample comparative analyses were also conducted in Africa and Asia. While the results align with the full sample model, minor differences were observed in the contradictory impact of human capital and policy effectiveness. The study provides various recommendations, such as investments in drought-resistant crops, alignment of agricultural policies with sectoral needs, and governance stability for dealing with political transitions.

title: Medical Debt and Insufficient Sleep Among U.S. Adults

detail.abstract: Medical financial hardship and debt are rising public health concerns in the United States. According to a recent estimate the burden of medial debt in the US is approximately USD 220 billion. This study examines whether inability to pay medical debt is associated with insufficient sleep or short sleep duration (i.e., average sleep duration of ≤ 6 hours) among US adults during pre-(2011-2013) and post-(2015-2018) Affordable Care Act (ACA) and in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic (2022 and 2024). Due to varied lived experiences and age-related differences in health issues and insurance coverage, assessments were performed by generations-boomers, generation X, and millennials. Furthermore, since both medical debt and sleep health are tied with socioeconomic positions, a naïve analysis may not capture the true association. We tried to overcome this problem by separately investigating the relationship across disaggregated income levels and performing random effect meta-analyses to obtain an overall estimate of the relationship for each generation. Nationally representative data from 2011 to 2013, 2015 to 2018, and 2022 and 2024 waves of the National Health Interview Survey (NHIS) were used to assess the relationship across 10 income subgroups within each generation. Robustness was checked through sub-sample analyses by sex. Sensitivity analyses were performed by considering a categorical specification of problems paying medical bills (i.e., no problems paying, had problems but were able to pay, and had problems and were unable to pay) instead of the binary inability to pay indicator. Results suggested that medical debt was generally associated with a greater risk of insufficient sleep among U.S. adults of all generations in both pre-and post-ACA periods as well as after the COVID-19 pandemic.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates whether China's structural dominance in rare earth elements (REE) and its associated geopolitical leverage can serve as a portfolio factor for asset allocation. We propose a Maximum Sharpe Ratio strategy incorporating rare earth equities, EV supply chains, aerospace & defense, gold, and U.S. Treasuries. Using historical ETF data from January 2018 to July 2025, we estimate expected returns and covariances with a 36-month rolling window and apply meanvariance optimization with quarterly rebalancing. The resulting portfolio achieves a Sharpe ratio of 0.43 compared to 0.73 for the S&P 500 benchmark, highlighting the risk-return trade-offs associated with rare earth exposure.

title: Democratic Proximity Theory: Autocratic Regimes and the Threat of Neighbouring Democratic Success
affiliations: University of Warsaw

detail.title: Democratic Proximity Theory: Autocratic Regimes and the Threat of Neighbouring Democratic Success
detail.abstract: This article develops and tests the Democratic Proximity Theory, which posits that autocratic regimes perceive democratic transitions in neighbouring countries with shared cultural and linguistic ties as direct threats to their regime stability. Unlike broader theories of democratic diffusion that emphasize geographic proximity alone, this theory highlights how culturallinguistic proximity intensifies the risk of democratic contagion, inspiring opposition and unrest within authoritarian states. Using the Russia-Ukraine conflict as a case study, the article examines how Ukraine's democratization efforts, rooted in a shared Slavic heritage and linguistic connections, have provoked heightened fears in the Kremlin of political destabilization and popular sympathy among Russian citizens. In response, Russia has employed a range of strategies including internal repression, nationalist propaganda, and hybrid warfare tactics to contain the spread of democratic ideals and maintain regime control. The case study illustrates the multidimensional nature of democratic proximity threats, and the sophisticated toolkit authoritarian regimes deploy to counter them. The article further explores the role of migration and diaspora networks as transnational vectors that amplify democratic influence across borders. This research contributes to the fields of democratization and authoritarian resilience by incorporating cultural and linguistic factors into the analysis of regime security and interstate conflict. The findings underscore the importance of identitybased dynamics in shaping political transitions and provide valuable insights for policymakers engaged in democracy promotion and conflict prevention in culturally interconnected regions. Finally, the article identifies directions for future comparative research to validate and refine the Democratic Proximity Theory across diverse geopolitical contexts.

title: Integrating Happiness Economics and Subjective Well-Being in Policy Evaluation -Evidence from Qatar
affiliations: SRTM University

detail.title: Integrating Happiness Economics and Subjective Well-Being in Policy Evaluation -Evidence from Qatar
detail.abstract: This chapter explores the field of Happiness Economics, an interdisciplinary approach that integrates economic and psychological insights to better understand human well-being. Unlike traditional economic models that emphasise income and consumption, Happiness Economics incorporates subjective well-being (SWB) indicators such as life satisfaction, emotional experiences, and perceived purpose. The chapter traces the historical evolution of happiness in economic thought, from classical philosophers to modern behavioural economics, and highlights key methodological developments, such as the use of large-scale surveys and econometric models (e.g., ordered probit and logit). It examines how happiness data can complement conventional indicators to provide richer insights into issues like inequality, globalisation, unemployment, and public health. The analysis includes empirical evidence from Qatar, where economic indicators such as GDP per capita and unemployment rate are assessed alongside subjective well-being metrics. Despite methodological challenges, including potential biases in self-reported data, the chapter argues that Happiness Economics offers a valuable framework for evaluating policy outcomes and improving quality of life. By emphasizing expressed preferences and subjective perceptions, this approach helps bridge the gap between economic policy and human experience.

title: Numerical Signal Design for Crypto Intelligence
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Numerical Signal Design for Crypto Intelligence
detail.abstract: This study presents a novel framework that bridges deterministic numerical algorithms with computational finance to support interpretable machine learning applications in cryptocurrency analysis. By applying Newton's method, the trapezoidal rule, and a hybrid Euler-Adams-Bashforth solver, we generate structured numerical features that capture convergence, integration precision, and differential dynamics, respectively. These feature vectors are constructed from both synthetically generated sequences and real AVAX-USD log-return data, enabling a direct comparison between theoretical numerical behavior and marketdriven fluctuations. A deterministic labeling rule, based on the parity of the integer sum of the features, defines class boundaries with geometric regularity, allowing the K-Nearest Neighbors classifier to operate in a feature space shaped by mathematically grounded transformations. The results reveal that classical numerical methods, when applied to financial time series, produce stable, class-separable patterns that are well-suited for local classification and boundary interpretation. Through decision boundary visualization, error convergence analysis, and joint feature interaction plots, the paper demonstrates that numerical approximation techniques can illuminate latent structural signals in crypto price behavior. This framework advances the integration of scientific computing and data-driven finance, offering a new paradigm for understanding digital asset dynamics through the lens of deterministic modeling.

title: Model Uncertainty
affiliations: Bonn Graduate School of Economics and IZA Institute of Labor Economics

detail.title: Model Uncertainty
detail.abstract: Mental models help people navigate complex environments. This paper studies how people deal with model uncertainty. In an experiment, participants estimate a company’s value, facing uncertainty about which one of two models correctly determines its true value. Using a between-subjects design, we vary the degree of model complexity. Results show that in high-complexity conditions people fully neglect model uncertainty in their actions. However, their beliefs continue to reflect model uncertainty. This disconnect between beliefs and actions suggests that complexity leads to biased decision-making, while beliefs remain more nuanced. Furthermore, we show that complexity, via full uncertainty neglect, leads to higher confidence in the optimality of own actions.

title: Green Before the Bell? Environmental Risk and the Decision to Go Public
affiliations: Lancaster University - Department of Accounting and Finance, Lancaster University - Lancaster University Management School and Lancaster University - Lancaster University Management School

detail.title: Green Before the Bell? Environmental Risk and the Decision to Go Public
detail.abstract: We study whether and how environmental risk influences firms' decisions to go public. Using panel data covering US private firms between 2010 and 2020, we find that higher environmental risk is associated with a lower likelihood of IPO. To address potential endogeneity concerns, we use the 2015 Paris Agreement as a quasi-natural experiment and conduct a difference-indifferences analysis, which reinforces the negative impact of environmental risk on IPO likelihood. This effect is weaker for firms with stronger incentives to go public: those with greater information asymmetry or growth potential. We also find that greater climate-related voluntary disclosure in a firm's SEC Form S-1 is associated with a higher likelihood of IPO. However, in the post-IPO years, firms exhibit worse environmental performance while facing fewer compliance penalties, consistent with strategic green washing that limits legal exposure without improving actual environmental performance.

title: Environmental and Health Costs of Europeʼs Shift from Gas to Coal Amidst the Energy Crisis

detail.title: Environmental and Health Costs of Europeʼs Shift from Gas to Coal Amidst the Energy Crisis

detail.abstract: The gas price explosion during the 2021/22 European energy crisis prompted a shift from gas- to coal-fired electricity production. Empirical evidence on the environmental and health consequences of such a fuel-price shock – as opposed to policy reforms – is scarce. We fill this gap by quantifying how exogenous gas price surges reorder coal-gas marginal costs and, in turn, affect emissions and health outcomes. Using daily data (2015–2023) for six EU countries with substantial gas-to-coal switching potential, we estimate a two-stage residual inclusion (2SRI) model to obtain causal effects of days on which gas is more expensive than coal. During the 510 days of the 2021/22 gas price surge when coal was cheaper, coal-fired generation rose by 23% (53 TWh, 95% CI: 43–63), driving a 10% increase in CO2 (36 Mt, 95% CI: 28–45 Mt), 19% in PM2.5 (187 t, 95% CI: 152–222 t), 10% in NOx (8,442 t, 95% CI: 6,573–10,715 t), and 24% in SO2 (16,238 t, 95% CI: 10,947–21,658 t). Applying literature-based damage factors, we find indicative increases in premature deaths and serious illnesses, with additional external health costs exceeding one billion EUR2021. All figures are computed relative to a model-based counterfactual in which gas remained the cheaper option and represent short-term effect that disregard longer-term structural adjustments. The results highlight the substantial welfare costs of fuel price shock-induced switching and inform the design of policies that internalize these externalities.

title: Legal Technology and Bias: A Threat to Fair Trial Rights?

detail.abstract: This paper examines whether bias in legal technology poses a threat to the right to a fair trial, a cornerstone of democratic justice systems. Drawing on examples from the UK, US, and EU, it critically analyses how algorithmic bias in tools like predictive recidivism algorithms, automated visa processing, and facial recognition systems can perpetuate discrimination, undermine judicial impartiality, and erode procedural fairness. Key arguments highlight the 'black box' nature of AI systems, which obscures decision-making processes, and real-world cases such as the COMPAS algorithm's racial disparities and the UK Home Office's biased visa tool. The findings reveal that while legal technology offers efficiency gains, inherent biases, stemming from flawed training data and opaque algorithms jeopardize Article 6 of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) protections in the UK. Existing safeguards, including data protection laws and judicial review, are insufficient due to enforcement gaps and limited transparency. As of 2025, with the EU AI Act partially in force, ongoing developments underscore the need for vigilance. The paper concludes that without robust reforms, such as mandatory bias audits and independent oversight, legal technology risks violating fair trial rights, recommending policy enhancements to ensure equitable integration into justice systems.

detail.abstract: This study presents the first comprehensive microeconomic analysis of blockchain transaction markets, introducing a novel framework for understanding dynamic pricing mechanisms and resource substitution effects in dual-resource blockchain systems. Using 998 daily observations from the TRON blockchain (September 2022-June 2025), I construct a master dataset integrating transaction volumes, resource costs, and network utilization metrics. My methodology combines price elasticity estimation, resource substitution analysis, and welfare optimization models to examine transaction market microstructure in a dual-resource environment. I find strong evidence for resource substitution between energy and bandwidth (elasticity:-0.831, R=0.737), heterogeneous price elasticities across transaction types (TRX transfers:-0.758, USDT:-0.054), and significant congestion pricing effects (t=-13.494, p<0.001). My welfare analysis demonstrates that dynamic pricing mechanisms could increase total welfare by 47.8% compared to current fixed-price schemes. The study establishes the first empirical foundation for blockchain transaction economics, providing evidence for optimal pricing strategies and resource allocation mechanisms in decentralized networks.

title: Sequential College Admission Mechanisms and Off-Platform Options
affiliations: Toulouse School of Economics, Institute for Fiscal Studies, University of Pennsylvania and Duke University - Department of Economics

detail.title: Sequential College Admission Mechanisms and Off-Platform Options
detail.abstract: The optimal functioning of centralized allocation systems is undermined by the presence of institutions operating off-platform—a feature common to virtually all real-world implementations. These off-platform options generate justified envy, as students may reject their centralized assignment in favor of an outside offer, leaving vacant seats in programs that others would have preferred to their current match. We examine whether sequential assignment procedures can mitigate this inefficiency: they allow students to delay their enrollment decision to potentially receive a better offer later, at the cost of waiting before knowing their final admission outcome. To quantify this trade-off, we estimate a dynamic model of application and acceptance decisions using rich administrative data from the French college admission system, which include rank-ordered lists and waiting decisions. We find that waiting costs are large. Yet, by improving students’ assignment outcomes relative to a standard single-round system, the sequential mechanism decreases the share of students who leave the higher education system without a degree by 5.4% and leads to large welfare gains.

title: Suraj Lamps Judgements: The Impact, the Effect and the Aftermath
affiliations: National Law School of India University, Bengaluru

detail.title: Suraj Lamps Judgements: The Impact, the Effect and the Aftermath
detail.abstract: This paper undertakes a comprehensive analysis of the Suraj Lamps judgments delivered by the Supreme Court of India and their enduring impact on property law, particularly the validity of property transfers executed through Sale Agreements (SA), General Power of Attorney (GPA), and Wills. The judgments marked a critical shift in curbing informal real estate practices, aiming to reduce stamp duty evasion, the proliferation of black money, and imperfect titles in property transactions. The paper evaluates the legislative and judicial aftermath, including the invalidation of Asha M Jain v. Canara Bank, and examines how statutory developments like the National Capital Territory of Delhi (Recognition of Property Rights of Residents in Unauthorised Colonies) Act, 2019 reacted to these rulings. It also assesses the practical efficacy of the judgments in tackling systemic challenges such as underreporting of property values, stamp duty leakage, and the persistence of black money, while recognizing the limitations posed by non-scientific guidance values and high compliance costs. Through case studies like Ghanshyam v. Yogendra Rathi and Maya Devi v. Lalta Prasad, the paper explores the evolving jurisprudence on possessory rights under Section 53-A of the Transfer of Property Act and clarifies the role of PoA as an enabling-not transferringinstrument. Further, it interrogates the "obsolescence" argument by comparing how various state-level stamp duty regimes had already addressed some loopholes prior to judicial intervention, albeit without adequately reinforcing the legal distinction between conveyance and mere possession. The conclusion places the Suraj Lamps judgment as a pivotal development in real estate reform-one that prioritizes legal clarity, safeguards socioeconomic property rights, and strengthens the transparency of India's property regime.

title: Green Fiscal Multipliers with Different Sovereign Debt Trajectories in EU Countries
affiliations: ISEG, Universidade de Lisboa, University of Lisbon, Roma Tre University and ISEG, Universidade de Lisboa - ISEG - Universidade de Lisboa

detail.title: Green Fiscal Multipliers with Different Sovereign Debt Trajectories in EU Countries
detail.abstract: This paper estimates the fiscal multipliers of green public spending using a linear Bayesian Panel VAR and a Smooth Transition VAR framework, with quarterly data for the period 1995Q1–2022Q4 for EU member states. We group EU member states based on similarities in debt trajectories and green spending intensity, forming three regional aggregates: Southern Europe, Eastern Europe, and Northern Europe. Our results show that green spending multipliers on GDP are generally below one, but the response of private investment is significantly stronger — particularly in Southern and Eastern Europe. Multipliers tend to be larger in periods of high public debt, suggesting that green fiscal expansions may be more effective during downturns. Another key finding is that in response to green spending shocks, both long-term interest rates and public debt tend to decline—especially in high-debt regimes—indicating improved market expectations about fiscal sustainability. In contrast, when we estimate the effects of a shock to total public spending net of green spending, we find that both interest rates and debt increase. This suggests that economic agents perceive green spending more favorably than undifferentiated fiscal expansions, likely due to its role in mitigating climate risks, lowering long-term energy costs, and signaling credible long-term policy commitments.

title: Exploring the Impact of Minimum Wage Increases on Crime: An Analytical Assessment Using the Becker Model and Empirical Evidence with Relevance to the UK Context

detail.abstract: This paper explores the potential impact of minimum wage (MW) increases on crime through the lens of Gary Becker’s economic model of criminal behaviour, which frames offending as a rational response to shifting incentives. Using this framework as an analytical foundation, the essay examines whether raising the MW can deter crime by increasing the opportunity cost of offending, particularly for low-skilled or marginalised workers. It draws on empirical research from both the UK and the US, finding that while MW rises can reduce crime, this effect is conditional on continued access to lawful employment. UK-based studies provide supportive evidence of crime reduction following MW reform, with little to no disemployment. However, US-based studies show that where MW hikes reduce employment - especially among young or low-skilled groups - crime may increase. The paper integrates refinements of Becker’s model, including Ehrlich’s time-efficiency framework and Braun’s U-shaped wage-crime hypothesis, to highlight the importance of stable, timely access to legal work. It concludes that MW policy may deter crime, but only where it does not undermine employment opportunities. The findings hold relevance for UK policy despite cross-jurisdictional differences, provided that local labour market conditions and demographic exposures are accounted for.

We find robust empirical evidence that firms targeted by climate lawsuits pay significantly higher spreads on their bank loans. These effects are more pronounced for firms with weaker environmental performance and higher ESG controversies. The results suggest that lender’s view climate litigation as a material risk factor, which is increasingly priced into debt contracts.

detail.title: Flourishing-by-Design: A Framework for Embedding Well-Being in AI-Driven Innovation
detail.abstract: Big Tech firms face mounting criticism for practices that undermine social welfare, ranging from monopolistic consolidation and attention-maximizing design to the erosion of mental health and civic trust. At the same time, corporate responsibility frameworks such as ESG remain ill-suited to assess the broader societal impacts of digital technologies, particularly due to inconsistent measurement and limited focus on actual outcomes. We propose a new paradigm-flourishing by design-that reorients corporate responsibility around the active promotion of human flourishing through AI-enabled services and platforms. Drawing on empirical insights from the Global Flourishing Study, we argue for a shift from risk-minimization toward outcome-oriented, value-driven product design. The framework advances a set of principles and design criteria that integrate AI ethics (e.g., fairness, autonomy, transparency) with multi-dimensional flourishing indicators (e.g., health, meaning, social connection) into the specification and evaluation of digital products. This approach offers scholars, policymakers, and industry leaders a more comprehensive lens for assessing the ethical performance of all firms and complements existing ESG efforts by anchoring responsibility in the lived experiences and well-being of end users.

detail.abstract: In the contemporary discourse surrounding human rights, global legal pluralism and the multi-level protection paradigm are gaining increasing attention as a response to the complexities of human rights enforcement in an interconnected world. This paper explores how multiple legal regimes-ranging from national to international-interact and function collectively to protect human rights in a multi-layered fashion. Specifically, it examines the role of regional courts, such as the Inter-American Court of Human Rights (IACtHR) and the European Court of Human Rights (ECtHR), in shaping national legal systems. Through a comparative lens, this article analyzes how Latin America and Europe have adopted varying approaches to human rights protection within this multi-level framework. It explores key legal concepts, including inter-legality, conventionality control, and subsidiarity, which underpin the multi-level protection paradigm. The paper also delves into case studies that illustrate how these concepts are applied in practice, such as Gelman v. Uruguay and Kimel v. Argentina (IACtHR), and Dudgeon v. United Kingdom and Von Hannover v. Germany (ECtHR). Finally, it reflects on the evolving role of states, which are increasingly engaging with international norms to enhance their regulatory capacity while maintaining sovereignty in the protection of human rights. The article ultimately advocates for a more integrated and cooperative approach to human rights governance, which combines national, regional, and global legal frameworks.

detail.abstract: Empirical evidence on the historical role of Compulsory Schooling Laws (CSL) for the spread of mass education is mixed at best. This is also due to the difficulty of identifying exogenous variation in the application of CSL. We exploit an almost unique feature of a CSL in 1877 Italy which was gradually implemented across municipalities based on the teacher to population ratio. This criterion generates a sharp discontinuity which can be exploited to estimate the causal effect of the early implementation of CSL on economic outcomes. Estimates based on a regression discontinuity design show that CSL had a positive long-term effect on innovation and industrial employment. Consistent with the main objective of the reform, CSL had a positive effect on human capital by increasing enrollment rates in technical schools and, more in general, the literacy rate. The results are robust to a series of placebo, falsification and manipulation tests. This study provides important policy implications in favor of the early implementation of CSL to increase the average level of education which, in turns, brings about positive effects on innovation and industrialization.

title: Domestic Violence in South Asia: Navigating Law, Culture, and Human Rights

detail.title: Domestic Violence in South Asia: Navigating Law, Culture, and Human Rights
detail.abstract: Domestic violence remains a persistent and under-addressed human rights concern across South Asia, shaped by patriarchal social traditions, rigid cultural expectations, and systemic indifference. Despite the presence of legal frameworks in many countries, the gap between law and enforcement continues to leave victims vulnerable and without complete access to justice. This paper critically checks the legal and constitutional responses to domestic violence in select South Asian jurisdictions, focusing on how statutory protections intersect with broader rights to life, dignity, and liberty. It highlights the challenges of enforcement, the role of courts in interpreting constitutional guarantees, and the influence of socio-cultural norms on the effectiveness of legal remedies. It reflects on the importance of integrating international human rights standards into domestic legal systems to better protect survivors. Ultimately, the paper argues for a more holistic, rights-based approach to addressing domestic violence one that combines legal reform with institutional accountability and socio-cultural change. Without meaningful implementation and sustained political will, legal protections risk remaining ineffective, especially for women in rural and marginalized communities.

detail.abstract: We present new monthly city-level and national measures of worker and firm search from 1900 to 1938, derived from scanned images of U.S. newspapers. To our knowledge, we are the first to systematically use the "situations-wanted" advertisements placed by job seekers. We document fresh insights into early 20th-century labor market dynamics: (1) worker and firm search efforts are procyclical; (2) posting costs affect advertising behavior and labor search intensity; (3) the Beveridge curve is stable over the last 125 years, with similar shifts following the 1918 flu and Covid-19 pandemic; and (4) regional and gender heterogeneity exists.

title: From Data to Strategy: A Public Market Framework for Competitive Intelligence

detail.title: From Data to Strategy: A Public Market Framework for Competitive Intelligence

detail.abstract: This paper introduces a dynamic, mathematically grounded, and fully data-driven framework for competitor analysis, index construction, and industry benchmarking-addressing fundamental limitations in traditional strategic approaches that rely on static classifications, internal disclosures, or proprietary data. Built entirely on publicly available financial signals-including firm-level equity prices, macroeconomic indicators, and sector ETFs-the framework replaces rigid taxonomies with a flexible, behaviorally revealed peer selection mechanism governed by coupled ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and speed-weighted Runge-Kutta integration. A stakeholder-aware thresholding scheme integrates strategic priorities without sacrificing analytical rigor. The resulting industry index is constructed using Self-Financing Hierarchical Risk Parity (SF-HRP), producing stable and interpretable portfolio weights. A Gram-Schmidt orthogonality ensures parsimony among macroeconomic factors (|ρ| < 0.05), enhancing robustness. Forecasting evaluations confirm that CNN-LSTM achieves superior performance (RMSE: 0.028, R²: 0.95), reducing error by over 80% relative to baseline LSTM models, while WGANs capture tail risk distributions (R²: 0.75). Critically, the framework demonstrates that high correlation does not imply redundancy-validated through multiscale residual analysis, information-theoretic modeling, and geometric submanifold representations. At its core, this research introduces the signal-based strategic interaction model, a new theoretical paradigm that reframes financial performance as real-time strategic communication. It establishes a generalized, industry-agnostic system for dynamic competition management-scalable, transparent, and responsive to market shifts-empowering firms of all sizes to identify peers, track competitive positioning, and inform strategy with unprecedented precision and accessibility.

One is that we have no idea how faithful or accurate this transcription of Smith's law lectures is. The other problem is that Smith himself may have repudiated the ideas contained in those early law lectures.

detail.title: Unravelling Business Models Sustainability Opportunities: The Case of Horticultural Farmers in Cartago, Costa Rica
detail.abstract: The agricultural sector plays a key role in shaping the transition towards sustainable food systems. However, agricultural producers face dual pressure: to mitigate environmental burdens while simultaniously ensuring the financial viability of their business. Based on a case study in Latin America, a horticultural farmers’ cooperative in Costa Rica sets out to investigate the environmental and economic implications of employing  agroecological practices and identify market barriers and opportunities for sustainable business models for smallholders. The different methods used included the Agroecology Criteria Tool to evaluate the most promising producers from the cooperative, and based on their practices, further research steps were developed. The Environmental Life Cycle Costing (E-LCC) enabled the comparison of the performance of cooperative producers with the business-as-usual scenario, to later internalise environmental externalities through the monetisation of carbon and water footprints. A market analysis facilitated an understanding of the current commercial context, identifying strengths and weaknesses in a co-designed and tailored business model (BM) proposal, which utilised the Business Model Canvas (BCM). The results provide insights into the main challenges and barriers encountered by the case study farmers in improving their sustainability performances and matching business trends and requirements. The E-LCC showed potential in presenting the main focal points in a particular production model, which were further exploited in a BMC design process. Findings can be used as input for further attempts of sustainable agribusinesses through a science-based BM proposal, tailored for horticultural fermers in the Central American region, facilitating their transition towards more sustainable food systems.

detail.abstract: We examine the role of government investment in defense capital as a deterrence tool. Using an optimal fiscal policy framework with endogenous disaster risk, we allow for an endogenous determination of geopolitical risk and defense capacity, which we discipline using the Geopolitical Risk Index. We show both analytically and quantitatively that financing defense primarily through debt, rather than taxation, is optimal. Debt issuance mitigates present tax distortions but exacerbates them in the future, especially in wartime. However, since additional defense capital deters future wars, the expected tax distortions decline as well, making debt financing a welfare-improving strategy. Quantitatively, the optimal defense financing in the presence of heightened risk involves a twice higher share of debt and backloading of tax distortions compared to other types of government spending.

detail.title: Paformer: Part Aware Transformer for Person Re-Identification
detail.abstract: Within the field of person re-identification (ReID), partial ReID methods are widely used to compare body parts between samples and measure feature distances. However, despite extensive research in this area, a significant gap remains: existing methods often lack explicit anatomical guidance, which leads to inconsistent capture of corresponding body-part features across different samples. This shortcoming undermines robust part-to-part matching and ultimately limits ReID performance. To address this, we propose Part Aware Transformer (PAFormer), a pose estimation based ReID model that facilitates precise part-to-part comparisons. To inject part awareness into the model, we introduce learnable parameters called ‘pose tokens’ that estimate the correlation between each body part and image regions. Furthermore, leveraging the enhanced anatomical awareness, PAFormer incorporates a learning-based visibility predictor to assess the degree of occlusion for each body part. Importantly, during inference, PAFormer operates without additional body part localization modules that are typically required by previous pose-based ReID methods. A set of extensive experiments show that our method outperforms existing approaches on well-known ReID benchmark datasets.
